summary: Email correspondence between attorneys regarding the victims' rights lawsuit 'Jane Does v. United States'. The email forwards the United States' response opposing the motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, suggesting the matter should be addressed in the civil suit against Epstein where he is a party.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Recipient of email discussing the United States' response to a motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement in the Jane Does v. United States case.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Recipient of email discussing the United States' response to a motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement in the Jane Does v. United States case.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney who filed the victims' rights suit against the United States on behalf of two victims and filed a motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the non-prosecution agreement and civil suit; the email notes that litigation regarding the agreement is more appropriate in the civil suit where he is a party.

connections.description: Edwards is an attorney representing victims in a civil suit against Epstein.
Both are attorneys copied on the same email regarding legal strategy in the Epstein case.

events.title: Filing of US Response to Motion to Unseal
events.description: The United States files a response opposing the motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement in the Jane Does v. United States victims' rights suit.

keyFacts: A victims' rights lawsuit titled 'Jane Does v. United States' was filed by attorney Brad Edwards on behalf of two victims.
The United States opposed a motion to unseal the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, arguing the issue should be litigated in the civil suit against Epstein.
The email indicates uncertainty over whether Edwards provided notice of his motion to unseal to Epstein's counsel.
The correspondence is from Kirkland & Ellis LLP, marked as confidential and potentially attorney-client privileged.
